data: Epitaph for Krimma, child of Aunakos

Plinth (support for a stele) with mouldings top and bottom, of the local sandstone; the upper moulding is damaged, principally at the corners. The plinth is the left one of a pair mounted on a single base, classified as an epitymbion of type C.
Single line of greek letters approximately centred on the face of the plinth

Small simple letters. Kappa has short equal arms, attached to the vertical; rho has small closed eye; mu has slanting first and final strokes, with the mid-strokes joining as a curve and only descending half-way; alpha is broad with straight bar, in one case slightly curved with the apex extending at the top; nu has shorter right vertical joining the diagonal above the line; omicron is small and mid-line.
The tomb has not been excavated fully, but the cemetery went out of use around the end of the 3rd century BCE or early 2nd century, offering a terminus ante quem
Tomb 69/70 of the necropolis in contrada Cardusa, where it remains in situ
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
La Necropoli di Abakainon: primi dati
G.M. Bacci e P. Coppolino, La Necropoli di Abakainon: primi dati (Messina: Regione Siciliana, 2009)
Nuove iscrizioni funerarie dalla necropoli di Abakainon
Girolamo Sofia, ‘Nuove Iscrizioni Funerarie Dalla Necropoli Di Abakainon’, Zeitschrift Für Papyrologie Und Epigraphik 206 (2018): 103–12
Κριμμα Αυνακου
epitaph for krimma, child of aunakos
ISic004415. Epitaph for Krimma, child of Aunakos

1Κριμμα Αυνακου

1ΚΡΙΜΜΑΑΥΝΑΚΟΥ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • text of Sofia 2018

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Krimma, child of Aunakos

commentary

The name Κριμμα lacks parallels (although note Κριμμάτιον (LGPN V3B: 13184) at Pythion in northern Greece, and is most likely an indigenous name; the same is true for Αυνακος. This plinth is one of a pair on a single base - a type attested several times in this necropolis - and the second plinth (ISic004416) is also inscribed and appears also to bear the name Αυνακος in the genitive as its second element, suggesting that the tomb is a double one for siblings. The same situation seems to be attested in the case of ISic004417 / ISic004418. The first name here appears to be in the nominative (which has a parallel in ISic001208), rather than the more commonly found genitive in this necropolis.

bibliography

  • Bacci and Coppolino 2009 28 fig.15 (and ref on p.113) https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002171
  • Sofia 2018 107 no.5 and fig.6 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001574
